question: Most common type of senile cataract -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i.e., CunieformMorphological types of senile cataracto Common morphological types of senile cataract are :-Cortical senile cataract (soft cataract):-Opacities in cortex may be of two types :-Cuneiform cataract:- Wedge shaped opacities (spokes) in the cortexPosterior subcapsular (Cupuliform) cataract:- Saucer shaped opacity under the posterior capsule.Nuclear senile cataract (Hard cataract) :- Opacity in the nucleuso Most common type of senile cataract is cunieform cortical (70%) followed by nuclear (25%) and cupuliform.

question: In senile nuclear cataract what type of myopia is seen-
exp: Ans. is 'b' i.e., Index myopia o Nuclear changes of aging induce a modification of refractive index of lens and produce an index myopia."Nuclear cataracts cause a general decrease in the transperancy of the lens nucleus. They are associated with index myopia "-- Ophthalmic study guideCauses of errors of refractiono Possible causes of ametropia are : -AxialIt is the commonest form of ametropia (both myopia and hypermetropia). In hypermetropia, there is an axial shortening of eyeball. So, image is formed behind the retina. In myopia, there is an axial lengthening of eyeball. So, image is formed in front of the retina. 1 mm change in axial length leads to ametropia of 3D. For example 1 mm shortening in axial length causes hypermetropia of 3D.CurvatureChange in the curvature of cornea or lens will cause ametropia. In hypermetropiaf the curvature of cornea or lens is lesser than normal. In myopia, there is increase in curvature of cornea or lens./ mm change in corneal curvature leads to 6-7 D ametropia.IndexIf refractive index of optical system is low, it will result in hypermetropia and high refractive index will result in myopia.Positional (Due to relative position of the lens)A forward shift of lens causes myopia, backward shift result in hypermetropia. Absence of lens (aphakia) causes hypermetropia.Excessive accommodationExcessive accommodation due to spasm of accommodation causes myopia.

question: Which of the following is true regarding concentration of proteins in senile cataract?
exp: Ans. a. More insoluble protein, less soluble protein (Ref: Exp Eye Res. 2004 July; 79(1): 3-9. Molecular genetics of age- related cataract by J. Fielding Hejtmancika and Marc Kantorowb)'Lenses with cataracts contain more insoluble proteins.'Lens ProteinsThe lens is very high (35%) in protein and is therefore sensitive to protein deficiency.In young individuals, most lens proteins are soluble (alpha, beta and gamma crystallines).Lenses with cataracts contain more insoluble proteins.With age, some crystallines become insoluble which is important in senile cataractogenesis.The lens capsule immunologically 'walls off' the lens proteins from the immune system.
opa: More insoluble protein, less soluble protein
opb: More soluble protein, less insoluble protein
opc: Equal concentration of soluble and insoluble protein
